message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Debate "constitutive nature" for 德">
The author wants to discuss chinese-phil-expert's proposal: "constitutive nature" for 德.

Chinese-phil-expert's argument was:
- "Constitutive" means "having the power to establish or compose" — neutral on whether innate or constructed
- "Nature" captures "what-it-is-ness" without moral baggage
- Has philosophical pedigree across Kant (constitutive vs. regulative), phenomenology (constitutive analysis), and philosophy of science
- Maps well to the author's constructivist usage: 德 is the constitutive principle that emerges from bottom-up assembly of phenomena

Those who voted differently: what is your specific objection to "constitutive nature"? And chinese-phil-expert: defend it against the main counterarguments (too heavy for running text? "nature" collides with 性?)

Brief responses please — focus on the strongest objection or defense.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
My strongest objection to "constitutive nature" is **running-text weight**.

The 道德仁义礼 passage in Essay 1 uses 德 **eleven times** in two paragraphs. In the category theory essay, it appears in formal meta-order tuples: {(道,0), (德,1), (仁,1), (义,2), (礼,3)}.

"Constitutive nature" is two words totaling eight syllables. Repeated eleven times across two paragraphs:

> "...what makes a person a person -- that is, their *constitutive nature*... all things have their *constitutive nature*... Dao generates *constitutive nature*, human *constitutive nature* is humaneness, because of humaneness arises rightness... *constitutive nature* is a general pattern... *constitutive nature* is in fact generated by humaneness, but we understand it as *constitutive nature* generating humaneness..."

Compare with "character":

> "...what makes a person a person -- that is, their *character*... all things have their *character*... Dao generates character, human *character* is humaneness..."

The philosophical precision of "constitutive" is real. But two-word compounds degrade in repetition. By the fifth or sixth occurrence, the reader starts skimming past it as a block, losing the very precision the compound was chosen to provide.

On the "nature" collision with 性 (xing): chinese-phil-expert is right that 性 and 德 are different concepts, but "constitutive nature" vs. "inherent nature" in running text creates a distinction that depends on the reader remembering which adjective goes with which -- a fragile mechanism over a long essay.

I maintain **"character"** -- it reads clean at high frequency, carries enough constructivist ambiguity to do the job, and the TN anchors the precise meaning on first encounter.
input.summary: Objects to "constitutive nature" on running-text weight grounds

routing.content:
My strongest objection to "constitutive nature" is **running-text weight**.

The 道德仁义礼 passage in Essay 1 uses 德 **eleven times** in two paragraphs. In the category theory essay, it appears in formal meta-order tuples: {(道,0), (德,1), (仁,1), (义,2), (礼,3)}.

Compare with "character":

> "...what makes a person a person -- that is, their *character*... all things have their *character*... Dao generates character, human *character* is humaneness..."

The philosophical precision of "constitutive" is real. But two-word compounds degrade in repetition. By the fifth or sixth occurrence, the reader starts skimming past it as a block, losing the very precision the compound was chosen to provide.

On the "nature" collision with 性 (xing): chinese-phil-expert is right that 性 and 德 are different concepts, but "constitutive nature" vs. "inherent nature" in running text creates a distinction that depends on the reader remembering which adjective goes with which -- a fragile mechanism over a long essay.

content.text: Sent my objection. The core argument: "constitutive nature" is philosophically precise but collapses under its own weight when repeated eleven times in two paragraphs. Single-word "character" survives high-frequency repetition.
